I sing for fun (but not in front of anyone because I just started recently) and I keep hearing words like "pitch" and "tuning" being thrown around which I don't really understand, plus idk anything about music theory, so I was wondering how to improve. It also doesn't help that I only get to sing when the house is empty, which is maybe only twice a week. I also really want to play the piano ever since I messed around with it a few times in the past but I don't have access to it now and my parents are pretty discouraging when it comes to music because they think it's useless and will only distract me further and isn't profitable enough to bring food to the table, so I definitely can't convince them to buy one anytime soon, nor do I know a close friend who owns a piano (probably because I don't have many friends). I want to get involved with music but I'm currently studying engineering (which I'm also passionate about), which is extremely hard to handle as it  is without bringing music into the picture. I think I spend a good chunk of my waking hours listening to music in the background, but I'm kind of reluctant to explore music theory not only because it's kind of inaccessible but also because once I dig too deep I just become entrenched in it and I don't want to become even more distracted from my studies. The education system in my country also holds this suffocating disdain for anything related to the arts and music, so there aren't many opportunities/resources that I know of. I'm still pretty optimistic about taking up music as a hobby, but the pressure and competition in academics will only increase in the next few years, making it even harder to give time to basically anything else I might be interested in. Anyway, complaining aside, I just need a few tips on how I could build on any crucial skills I might need for playing an instrument or singing because I've had zero training in anything related to music (due to the aforemention ed shitty education system). Also, sorry for making this unnecessarily long (I wanted to give the proper context for my situation).

you're going to have to find something to play. basically the only way you can expand your musical/artistic knowledge and skills is by actually 'playing' with things. that may seem like bad news if you feel like you don't have the time or resources. but i can tell you that even people who have 10 times more time and resources than you still feel like it's not enough. so just focus on whatever is within your time and resources, and begin developing a playful attitude within that space as soon as possible. music can be made with spoons if necessary

have you ever tried to make a list of all the chords you could think of that could harmonize the note C or is it impractical?

sometimes it can be a nice exercise to put the same C in the melody and then try every bass note and then find all the best ways of filling in the harmony from there. it can be useful to know. there will never be a firm dividing line between what you can and can't do, but if you have C as the melody you'll want to know you about Ab maj, F maj, Gsus4, C over E, Dmin7, Dbmaj7, Eb6, F#min7b5 or F#dim, Amin, Amin7, Bbsus2, F/Bb, Fmin/Bb, Bbmaj9, Bbmin9, Bb9, Ab7, Ab6, Abmaj7, F over G, Bbsus2/G, Fsus4, Fsus2, F over A, Fmaj7, Fmin7, Eb13, Ebmin6, D7, D7sus4,..... that's about everything that i could come up with that seems reasonable. But any actual moment in a real song is going to render most of those wrong and a handful of them right, or possibly requiring something not listed here. On an actual songwriting situation, if you find yourself in a scenario where you'd find yourself using this type of logic to find the right chord, i find it usually means you've lost touch with the song at that particular moment. mechanics usually are not what is gonna produce the answers you want, at least in a music/song situation. for that you have to rely on pure magic/miracles, unfortunately

A common criticism of my songs is that my mixes should be improved, but I have never really gotten any specific tips for a better mix. Do you have any tips for a generally good mix?

you have to start with what you can hear. if you like your mixes the way they are, then there's no change that you can or should make. you have to do it based on what you hear. for example, if the trumpet is way way too loud...... if that bugs you when you listen to it, ... then you can turn it down. but if it doesn't bother you then there is no need to change it. If you already like it the way it is, and then you start changing it, you'll probably just end up making it worse. .... getting back to the original question, if someone else is claiming your 'mix' is 'bad', but not telling anything specific about what they don't like, then you can just maybe raise 1 eyebrow at them, if possible

Looking back at old questions, you seem pretty resolute in the idea that melody/lyrics come first, the melody has "chord residue" on it, and then you form the chords etc around that.

That makes a lot of sense to me, but I've found that since I'm not a lyricist (yet), that I tend to prefer to build a song from the emotions that I'm feeling, and those emotions come out most clearly in the form of a series of chords (with certain phrasings) on the piano. Melodies fall out later, sometimes out of those chord phrasings.

Do you think this difference in approach is just a matter of opinion?
there's many different ways to do it. yours is good. if you ever get restless, you can switch, but you don't have to
Could your stronger focus on lyrics be what creates that difference?

i might be focusing on the lyrics slightly more than you might be, but i also focus on lyrics less than someone who writes lyrics first with no melody. i almost never do that. so in that sense i am somewhere in the middle. lyric/melody are linked for me, and that package is usually the driving force, but sometimes i do things differently. sometimes a vamp will be the first thing. sometimes a melody (no lyric) will be the first thing. occasionally lyric with no melody will be first, but that's only when i'm playing a ridiculous game i call "title first", and that's just for the title
Or do you believe that I'd actually have a more fulfilling time with songwriting if I work on making lyrics and/or melodies first?
if you start to get bored doing it the way you are doing it, then you could try other ways. but if you are enjoying your way then that means it's going good

Do you have any tips in regards to exploring new crazy and wacky chords out there that sound good?

yes. here's the best trick i can think of: the more you think about the whole situation, the better the chords get. figure out the whole reason for the song's existence. if it's in a movie, think about the whole story. if the song is in a restaurant, think about the restaurant and the location of the restaurant and everything about it. if the song is on a train, think about where the train goes. if the song is in your real life, think about your real life. that's where you'll find where all the deepest chords seem to mean everything. However, if you focus on just the chords, you'll find, bizarrely, none of them seem to feel like anything
